millsfield:images_texts:
EMERGENCY
INSTRUCTIONS
FOR YOUR SAFETY
JUST IN CASE...
PAN AMERICAN
Super-7 Clipper Service
CLIFFER. TRADE MARK, FAN AMERICAN WORLD AIRWATS. INC

omergency
Landings
Put your arms through the loops -
then place jacket over your head.
An emergency landing is most improbable when
you are flying in a Clipper because it is a multi-
engine aircraft with ample reserve power to
remain aloft under emergency conditions.
Just the same, every precaution has been taken
for your safety should trouble arise.
Your
Clipper crew has practiced many times what to
do in an emergency and your Clipper carries
hundreds of pounds of safety equipment includ-
ing an emergency radio set capable of sending
an SOS constantly hundreds of miles in all di-
rections. Life rafts are stowed away in strategic
locations, each outfitted with food and water.
If an emergency should arise, your Clipper
Captain will first radio for assistance. Next, he
will inform you-
even though the situation is
far from serious. We believe in keeping every
passenger completely informed at all times.
Your part is to cooperate and remain calm.
Let's just make believe
Let's make an imaginary emergency landing.
First, make yourself as comfortable as pos-
sible.
Remove things which obviously could
hurt you such as pencils, pens, sharp jewelry.
Men, loosen your collars. Ladies, please take
off those high-heeled shoes.
YOUR LIFE JACKET
Next, if it is a water landing, you will be in-
structed to put on a modern,
lightweight life
jacket which you will find in a compartment
under your seat, or in a compartment indi-
cated by your cabin attendant. To remove the
jacket from its plastic container, pull the tab
across the top of the bag.
Then slip it on ac-
cording to the directions shown in the next
panel.
Then you should immediately adjust the back
of your seat to a forward, vertical position and
fasten seat belt. A short time before the emer-
gency landing you will be given the order
"Brace for landing." Clasp your hands under
your knees and bend forward with head on lap
as nearly as possible. This, along with your
cushioned seat, will relieve any sudden stop.
When plane comes to a stop in its forward
landing motion, open your seat belt and follow
the next instructions of your crew to evacuate
the aircraft.
grasp straps under
your arms and pull
down sharply to snap breakaway
threads and release straps.
Pull straps down
until back flap is fully
extended, as shown
at left and below.
Pull tab-end straps in an outward
motion until jacket is snug.
To inflate pull down sharply
on the two inflation knobs;
Mouth Inflation Tube:
Used only further inflations
pulled. To use, blow into mouthpiece.
DO NOT INFLATE JACKET IN CABIN
The inflated jacket would hamper passing
through the emergency exit.
Pull off handle cover.
EMERGENCY
EXITS
Turn handle upward.
Push window
Pull escape
rope down
You have probably located the emergency exit
nearest you-there is an "Emergency Exit"
over the window. Seat backs opposite the emer-
gency exits may be reclined fully, (some may also
be pushed forward and down flat against seat cush-
ions). Just below the window is a plastic cover over
a red nanore. run on the top or the plasue cover to
remove. Turn handle upward and then push out on
aft end of window exit until it latches wide open.
Members of the Flight Crew will be in charge of
the life rafts. Your sea-going raft has adjustable
sides and sun shade to protect you from the sun,
cold, and water spray. If it is a land emergency
landing, then reach up, grasp tab at top center of
exit window frame and pull escape rope down until
it is fully extended outside the plane. Then passen-
gers lower themselves to ground by the escape rope.
EVACUATION
SLIDE
For Land Landings
Attach floor straps here.
Open door and kick out slide.
Slide to ground.
If an emergency landing is made on land, the emer-
gency slide will also be used to evacuate passengers.
Ordinarily your crew will take care of the slide, but
you may be asked to assist. The emergenev slides
are packed in neat pouches on the inside of the
main cabin door and on the right hand rear door
exit, and attached as shown in the above photo. Un-
snap the entire front flap of the pouch; pull out the
blue and vel low strap fittings and attach to similar
colored fittings on the floor.
Then open the cabin
door and kick out the slide. Two men, selected by
the crew, should then slip to the ground and hold
the extended end of the slide away from the plane.
Other passengers will then jump into the slide in
sitting position and slide to the ground.

IN CASE OF ANY
EMERGENCY LANDING
REMEMBER THESE SAFETY RULES
IN EMERGENCY EXIT.
Know the location of the emer-
gency exit nearest you. There is
a sign that reads "Emergency
Exit"' above each one.
2
Know the location of your life
jacket—it's underneath your
seat, or in the compartment in-
dicated by your flight attendant.
3
Loosen collar and tie. Remove
glasses and sharp objects from
pockets. Put on life jacket, if
instructed, and fasten seat belt.
4
Adjust seat to vertical position.
Assume proper posture to relieve
strain of possible sudden stop.
5
Never inflate your life jacket
inside cabin. Wait until you
get outside the plane.
Be calm and cooperative until help comes.
Follow the instructions of your aircraft officers.
PRINTED IN U.S. A.
F30-4040
1-58-7C
2002.127.411
properties.sfomuseum:description: Safety information card issued by Pan American World Airways for its Douglas DC-7 “Super-7 Clipper” fleet; double-sided tri-fold gray sheet with photographic images and illustrations and text demonstrating safety instructions and emergency procedures; identification code F30-4040 1-58-7C, revised 1-58.
